title: Wednesday, 5th June 2019

The official explanation is that the enlarged co would not have sufficient capital to satisfy PRA capital requirements.

Non-Standard Finance PLC (NSF:LSE): Last: 45.11, down 1.89 (-4.02%), High: 47.10, Low: 45.11, Volume: 169.51k
11:13 am
BE11:13am

And NSF -- whose 4% fall takes the shine off Provident's 16% rise, Woodford mark-to-market fund followers! -- has to wear a bunch of costs.

BE11:13am

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:13am

Deal-related costs will be treated as an exceptional item in the H1 2019 results and are expected to come to between £10.0-10.5m (before VAT), representing c39% of our FY19 forecast statutory PBT (£25.9m). NSF has confirmed that such fees will be met from its existing resources. Despite the exceptional cost, NSF remains committed to its progressive dividend policy and is expected to pay an interim dividend later this year (we have an estimated DPS of 3.3p for FY19, equivalent to c£10.4m).

11:13 am
BE11:14am

This is likely to place pressure on the NSF share price given the impact of the deal-related costs on the bottom line and questions about where the business goes from here. We maintain our Reduce on NSF and Hold on Provident Financial.

BE11:14am

One place NSF could go is ... into Provident Financial!

AMALtd Mornin
BE11:14am

There's a genuine suggestion that Prov should Pac-Man.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Via John Cronin at Goodbody.

nightingale20201 @BE (re Peel Hunt's note)...sounds like shorts NSF to me....capitalism could be cruel/..let's see whether Woodford would stand by NSF or PFG
BE11:15am

To be clear, neither NSF nor PFG are inadequately capitalised. Furthermore, the enlarged NSF Group would have been appropriately capitalised were PFG to have become a wholly-owned subsidiary of NSF. However, the problem, from a capital adequacy perspective, was because of the expected level of minority interests at the stage of completion, i.e., because NSF could not reasonably expect that PFG would become a wholly-owned subsidiary at completion based on the level of PFG shareholder acceptances (53.54% as at 15:00 on 24th May) and publicly stated large shareholder opposition to the deal. This meant that the NSF Group would not have sufficient regulatory capital on a consolidated basis at completion.

BE11:16am

PFG sat at its 12-month low yesterday, closing at 446p – down 15% from the price at which it traded before the initial offer was made by NSF. The incremental newsflow in relation to PFG’s restructuring progress and financial performance has been overwhelmingly positive since this date. While the quality of the PFG management team was called into question during the offer period (and 3 major shareholders in PFG may be considered to have ongoing concerns, something we weren’t aware of before the initial offer by NSF was made), we believe that PFG delivered a very strong defence and won the ‘momentum battle’ as it were. Furthermore, we would add that PFG may turn full-tilt and launch a bid for NSF, potentially seeking to take advantage of any further NSF price weakness. Given that the proposed combination was, at its most fundamental level, grounded in strategic logic (and we believe that market participants broadly agree with our view) as well as the fact that PFG management was careful to never really scotch the synergies argument, there is a prospect that the prey could become predator (as we have previously written). Finally, it’s surely onwards and upwards for PFG on a standalone basis – and we expect to see further material restructuring progress as the year progresses and we look forward to the upcoming Capital Markets Day. As a parting thought, we previously noted that a third party bidder would be more likely to surface after the deal with NSF was struck (or not) – could PFG come into play now we wonder?

hornblower if time the JP Morgan note on AO World please
11:17 am
BE11:18am

There's some attraction to the idea of a Pac-Man. Do shareholders (which overlap substantially, for obvious reasons) really care who manages the enlarged group?

nightingale20201 @ BE ...PFG & Amigo????
BE11:18am

The pressure to bail out one shareholder in particular might have lessened, but if the deal made sense on paper one direction then maybe .....

Snowman sadly for him he probably ends up having to place Ox Nanapore ...to Goldmans ... ahead of high profile IPO
BE11:19am

..... anyway, here's Numis. Long term buyers of Prov.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

We believe Provident will have to take a charge of c.£20m to cover the costs of the deal, but the group retains surplus capital and is being valued at just 6.7x 2020 earnings. Compellingly cheap now the
risk of having to support NSF has passed. Recovery is underway and the group remains a market leader in all business lines. However, the largest shareholder has a closed fund with substantial redemptions and the reasons why the original 49% of shareholders supported the offer still remain. Nevertheless, we believe the current share price has been driven by the market valuation of NSF and the probability of its offer succeeding, not by the fundamental value of Provident as it continues its gradual recovery.

SupposeToBeWorking... Who's buying the cold fusion stuff? Ark capital or softbank?
BE11:20am

And Panmure.

red says a lot that the share price goes up by 15% when a woodford bid fails.
BE11:20am

Despite the disruption, cost and impact of the uncertainty, we continue to believe in the turnaround by the current PFG management, as evidence by the reassuring trading update on 3 May. Management’s goals are receivables growth of 5-10% pa, ROE of 20-25% and dividend cover of greater than 1.4x. We believe these are achievable and with PFG trading on 2019E P/BV and PE of 1.8x and 7.8x for RoE of 21.8% we maintain our BUY rating.

Because everyone knows you can get some oil out of a fractured basement. The problem, historically, has been getting it out with any reliability.

BE11:30am

Which leads us onto talking about seismic waves in granite versus basalt and Vietnamese fields from the 1970s ... but let's not head down that path.

Flaneur Anyone else ever suspect that these subprime lenders were just free market channels for social welfare distribution/ debt alleviation instead of 'naked' helicopter money policies? Or is it just my fevered mind that imagines these things?
BE11:31am

Instead, here's Stifel.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

First oil reduces downside probability, we believe. With both wells flowing oil at a stabilised rate for 72 hours (reaching and maintaining 20 kb/d), today's announcement marks the successful conclusion of the 24-day FPSO start-up process (hydrocarbons introduced May 11). While guidance is that only 12 months' production can distinguish high vs low case reservoir performance - with the former capable of re-rating the shares towards/beyond our target price, we believe - an in-line start-up suggests the geological model is robust and the kit is working well.

BE11:31am

Here's what happens next:

BE11:31am

Warwick Deep exploration well result – early July
First commercial oil lifting – July
Capital Markets Day with first interpreted data – mid July
Lincoln Horizontal appraisal well result – September
Warwick Crestal Horizontal exploration well result – November

11:31 am
BE11:32am

And:

SupposeToBeWorking... @Flaneur what about PPI claims?
BE11:32am

No changes to our valuation. Our target price is set at risked Core NAV + Contingent upside and is unchanged at 130p.

BE11:32am

• We assign 32p/shr to Core NAV, which includes the Lancaster Early Production System still risked at 85% plus corporate items.

Flaneur I suspected this as I know of someone turned down for credit until they put the number of dependent children into the mix. The credit was then advanced in full.....(@Suppose - yes that too)
11:32 am
BE11:33am

• Our Contingent asset base includes full-field developments of c.500M boe each at Lancaster and Greater Warwick (GWA), each risked at 50%. We also include value for the planned one-well tieback from GWA to Lancaster.

BE11:33am

• Our upside NAV, not yet contributing to our target price, attributes value to the c.1.2B bbls of resource at Halifax and the upside case for GWA.

BE11:33am

And WH Ireland.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

In our opinion, this represents a tremendous achievement for Hurricane and a remarkable milestone for the UK oil & gas industry, given this is the first commercial production of oil from a fractured basement field. Nevertheless, the FPSO is simply operating as it was designed and the wells are simply behaving in line with expectations and their known capacity to produce oil. Likewise, the slow and steady ramp-up of production is very much, to our minds, a low-risk operational development, which we thought would have positive implications for the share price. We believe the share price run has further to go as the company delivers further good operational developments, which are essentially expected and low-risk. Investors in recent months have essentially made material gains while incurring very minimal risk. Conceptually, the time to be taking profit from this “trade” would be when production begins to shed light on the long-term capacity of the wells to produce at 20,000 b/d. However, for reference we believe that the wells will indeed be very productive into the long-term.

All in, HUR remains a BUY for a number of reasons going into mid-2019. Investors who have followed our recommendation and mid-term “trading” thesis should, in our opinion, be relaxed and anticipate further gains from low-risk operational developments. We also believe the longer-term more fundamental and value based investment thesis is compelling for HUR.

Punter @Snowman, igood point you make and perhaps reason to stay away from HL until that is clarified. HL have an obvious preference for funds as they get an annual 0.45% on funds vs nil on investment trusts, which usually have lower charges and perform better so ought to be recommended instead.
Omikin @Flan - nah, it's just rapacious capital finding a niche to extract even from the weakest, and highly successfully.

Potential adds are Network Intl (NETW LN, 135th), Future (FUTR LN, 289th), PPHE Hotel (PPH LN, 313th), Kainos (KNOS LN, 319th), 4imprint (FOUR LN, 321st), Paypoint (PAY LN, 322nd) and now Marstons (MARS LN, 333rd). Potential deletes are Kier (KIE LN, 525th), Indivior (INDV LN, 490th), Stobart (STOB LN, 457th), Just Group (JUST LN, 417th), Saga (SAGA LN, 394th), Civitas Social Housing (CSH LN, 392nd) and 888 (888 LN, 383rd). These names are unchanged from our last update despite some big moves in 888 and SAGA today. Aveva and JD Sports could leave to join FTSE100. JUST could see overall demand due to a 10.3% share increase.

BE11:57am

Jefferies incoming:

BE11:57am

Though further management departures at Aviva are disappointing, especially given Tom's track record as CFO, it is not all that surprising given that the CFO was appointed by the former CEO. In addition, Jason Windsor brings to the role extensive experience at Aviva (having joined in 2010, before his predecessor), most notably from his role as Chief Capital and Investments Officer, prior to being appointed CFO of Aviva UK. To our mind, Jason's UK experience complements well the experience of the new CEO Maurice Tulloch at Aviva International.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

And UBS:

BE11:58am

We believe the CFO did a good job and his departure does put some added focus on the financials of the company ahead of the investor update on 6 June and at a time when a lack of visibility on strategic changes challenges the LT investment case. However, our numbers indicate there are no financial constraints at play in the business and that the dividend strategy and deleveraging plan are well supported. We think that strong management commitment to the dividend on 6 June can support some re-rating and normalisation of the yield vs UK life peers

Forester In my days passing your driving test was just about the best moment of your life...for my eldest 3 there are at best "indifferent" to getting on the road in their own car given available alternatives.
BE11:58am

Whilst the new strategic direction of Aviva has yet to be communicated, this departure puts some additional spotlight on the financials and is unhelpful for sentiment with the latest UBS Evidence Lab Market Thinking Game survey indicating investors remain bearish on Aviva shares. A c.8% 2019E yield implies the market is pricing risks into this dividend. Whilst caution is warranted here given uncertain strategic changes ahead and prior dividend history, our numbers indicate management has the tools to deliver given healthy hold-co cash (UBSe £1.6bn) and solvency dividend cover (1.7-1.8x). Enhanced detail on the 1) delivery of debt reduction targets and 2) upside from self-help cost saving should also help the near-term investment case.

red @Flaneurits a massive worry for british high streets. i just wouldnt touch anything there and its affecting my judgement in other countries to be honest, when u can see the end game.

BE12:00pm

Sustainable book value growth is central to addressing the market's growth concerns. Strategically, building a leading UK composite insurer (organically and inorganically) with a bigger mix of P&C is one path that can achieve this and recent FT reports would support this. But our experience indicates it will take time to deliver with many untested complexities and capital investment needed. We expect limited detail on 6 June, with growth initiatives focused on 'self-help'. Lower digital spend, strategic investment costs and head office synergies could potentially deliver a 3-5% uplift on underlying EPS.
